regular-body:
sometimeisbetterthannotime:

Quick! I have the opportunity to record something! What should I do?

Siiiiince you ask …

  1. Do a bit from a radio play! Here’s a mostly SFW transcript you can read from. Here’s a very not-safe-for-work one. Here are more. I think they both show off what you can do with just your voice that you really can’t do in any other medium, written or performed.
  2. Make up your own story. Pretend like you’re telling someone a bedtime story, or the plot of a movie you like, or anything really. Must have at least six characters in it, so you can show off your voice. Throw in extra characters – I remember doing an improv comedy skit in 1996 in which we did “Jack and the Beanstalk”, except Jack was just interested in girls, and the Giant had a grandmother who was a sweet old thing really. Even if it’s crap, it’s voice-acting/improv practice!
  3. Write and then perform a comedy monologue. Here’s a monologue that Peter Sellers does as an old man, reminiscing fondly about the things kids would do in his village when he was just a wee mite. The whole gag is to do something completely absurd while making it sound like the most ordinary thing in the world.
  4. Eh, do the Aristocrats. Or don’t. Or do. (Just don’t use that crazy voice like scratching your nails on a whiteboard (or do)).

‘smy wishlist!
